title: What comes after quantum computing which is more powerful than quantum computing? - Quora

response.answer_text: “More powerful” isn’t really very well defined in this context. There’s nothing that a quantum computer can compute that a classical computer cannot also compute. It just appears that there some classes of problems that a quantum computer can solve faster. But quantum computers aren’t likely to be practical for a very long time. You’re not going to be running a quantum version of Chrome, for example. I doubt they’ll ever be more than highly specialized coprocessors like GPUs. If that’s the case, then it’s hard to argue that a GPU is “more powerful” than a regular processor—it does some things very well, but others not. The general-purpose processor is more useful across the whole range of tasks we want computers to perform. So, if you want a purely theoretical measure of “power”, then a quantum computer is no more powerful than a Turing machine. We don’t really even have any theoretical model of computing that’s more powerful than a Turing machine. If you want a practical, utilitarian measure of “power”, then quantum computers are less powerful than classical computers outside of a pretty small problem domain.
